title: Where Is Everybody?
description:
A man with no memory of who he is finds himself in a strange empty town.

Directed by: Robert Stevens. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.theme_name: what if I woke up in a strange place and didn't remember how I got there
themes.motivation: Ferris wandered into an empty town, not knowing who he was or how he had gotten there.

themes.theme_name: what if I were all alone in the world
themes.motivation: The story followed Ferris all alone in an empty town. Moreover, Ferris found a carousel stocked full of a book entitled "The Last Man on Earth," which raised the question of whether Ferris himself might be in such a predicament.
Ferris went nuts for lack of human companionship.
Ferris went nuts for lack of human companionship.
Ferris speculated that he was in a dream and would soon wake up - which was the case, of sorts.
Ferris wandered into an empty town, not knowing who he was or how he had gotten there.
Ferris was earmarked for a return trip to the Moon.
Ferris entertained the idea that "the bomb" might be the explanation as to why nobody was around, but he quickly dismissed this theory on the ground that no infrastructure had been damaged.
After his ordeal, Ferris felt trepidation about his upcoming trip to the Moon, which would see him spend over 400 days alone in space.

title: One for the Angels
description:
A pitchman talks Death (Murray Hamilton) into sparing his life until he makes one last great pitch, but threatens the life of a little girl in the process.

Directed by: Robert Parrish. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: Death appeared as an impeccably dressed American man.

themes.theme_name: the need to prove one's self
themes.motivation: Lew had never made a truly successful big pitch in his life, and he expressed a desire to do so before he completed it.
In the end Lew gave his life in exchange for that of a little girl.
Lew came up with a clever scheme to cheat death and live on indefinitely because he was quite happy to be alive.
Lew showed his craft as a peddler of trinkets when he made such a captivating pitch that Death himself became late for an appointment.
Lew was informed of his impending death.
Lew was notably kind to children.
Lew cheated death only to learn that a young girl would die in his place.

title: Mr. Denton on Doomsday
description:
A town drunk faces an infamous killer after magically regaining his gunfighting skills.

Directed by: Allen Reisner. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.theme_name: live by the sword die by the sword
themes.motivation: The moral of the story was simply this, and very nearly spelled out by Al Denton.

themes.theme_name: life in the American Wild West
themes.motivation: We saw a stereotyped depiction of life in a town on the American frontier in the 19th century.
Al Denton was an alcoholic wreck until he came in possession of a mysterious gun that he found lying on the road.
Al Denton, who was once known as the quickest draw in town, had become an alcoholic wreck and the laughingstock of the community.

themes.theme_name: seeing the error of one's ways
themes.motivation: Al Denton had given up his gunslinging way after he'd shot dead a 16 year boy in a duel, and turned to the bottle there after.
The young upstart gunslinger Mr. Grant came to town to challenge the seasoned old gunslinger Al Denton.
Local rummy Al Denton was forced to sing and dance to get drink.
Al Denton ultimately laid the smack down on a man who making him sing and dance to get a drink.
Mr. Grant challenged Al Denton to a duel to prove he was the quickest draw in town.
Mr. Grant wished to best Al Denton in a duel so that he would be regarded as the quickest gunslinger in town.
Al Denton was torn up inside over having shot dead a 16 year old boy in a duel some years prior.
There was a regular quacksalver except he had a potion that worked.
The quacksalver gave Al Denton a tincture that gave him perfect aim for 10 seconds after drinking it.

title: The Sixteen-Millimeter Shrine
description:
An aging movie star rewatches her old films in an attempt to recapture her youth.

Directed by: Mitchell Leisen. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: Barbara refused to owe up to the fact tat she was not a young actress sensation anymore.
Barbara dreamed of the days when she was a pretty young start.
Barbara locked herself up in a dark dank room watching her old films day after day.
Barbara was a passionate aging actress yearning for the roles of yore.
Barbara got sad and insulted whenever her age became topical.

themes.theme_name: wishing or wanting something really hard makes it happen
themes.motivation: Barbara willed herself into a movie.
Barbara's agent Danny tried to help her escape from the mental prison she's trapped herself in.
The story revolved around Barbara, an aging actress who became offended when a Hollywood producer offered her a bit role as a 40 something mother.
Barbara's maid Sally was shocked to find that Barbara had somehow become transported into a movie.

title: Walking Distance
description:
An ad executive under pressure at his job visits his old hometown, only to find himself returned to his childhood.

Directed by: Robert Stevens. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.theme_name: what if I found myself in the past
themes.motivation: Martin suddenly realized he was in the past of his childhood years in his old home town
Martin was thinking about all the things of his childhood.
It seemed the moral of the story was that success doesn't bring happiness - Martin was happier during his carefree youth.
Busy businessman Martin regretted not enjoying his glorious childhood days more and exhorted his younger self to do better.
Martin met his father of yore.

themes.theme_name: what if I met myself from a different time
themes.motivation: Martin met his childhood self.
Martin tried to save his younger self from an accident but ended up being the one to cause it.

title: Escape Clause
description:
A mean-spirited hypochondriac afraid of dying sells his soul to the Devil for immortality.

Directed by: Mitchell Leisen. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.theme_name: be careful what you wish for
themes.motivation: Walter wished for nothing less than immortality, but he became consumed by boredom once he got it.
Walter found that immortality was not all he thought it'd be - he became bored.
Walter and Ethel Bedeker.
Walter was ill-tempered and mean towards all around him.
Walter made a literal deal with Satan that saw Walter get virtual immortality in exchange for his soul.
Walter sought to live on for practical eternity.
Satan made an appearance in the guise of a rotund man who went by the peculiar name of Cadwallader.
Walter sold his soul to Satan himself in exchange for virtual immortality.
Walter found himself bored with immortal life.
Bored with immortality, Walter confessed to killing his wife thinking he'd be sentenced to an exciting death, yet was condemned to an even more boring life in prison.
Walter threw himself in front of a train, drank enough poison to kill 12 men, and threw himself off the rooftop of a building, but all to no avail as he had been granted immortality.
Walter believed himself to be sick and wouldn't take the doctor's word for it that he was perfectly healthy.
Walter lamented his impending or eventual demise, asking rhetorically why we can't live a thousand years instead.

themes.theme_name: coping with the death of a spouse
themes.motivation: Walter was unfazed when his wife plunged to her death before his very eyes.
Walter was notably cruel to his wife and didn't skip a beat when she died.
Walter claimed, falsely, that he had killed his wife.
Walter looked forwards to the electric chair.

title: The Lonely
description:
In the year 2046, a convicted man serving his sentence on an uninhabited asteroid is given a female robot (Jean Marsh) for companionship.

Directed by: Jack Smight. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: Corry was dying of loneliness on some far flung asteroid until he was given a female android companion.
It was illustrated that people may go mad if they are deprived of human company for a very long time.
The story was an early example of something to posit the question of whether and to what an extent a machine can be human enough to warrant our sympathy.
Corry was given the female android Alicia to keep him company while he served out a 50 year sentence otherwise alone on some far flung asteroid.
Corry gradually fell in love with his android companion Alicia.

Allenby took pity on Corry and delivered him things, like a female android, to help him keep his sanity while he served a 50 year sentence for murder on some far flung asteroid. Later, Corry refused to leave the asteroid without Alicia on the ground that she was a woman, not a mere robot. Note that while Corry had a romantic interest in taking Alicia back to Earth with him, he did not use this as a justification for the necessity of bring her along.
The story followed a convicted murderer named Corry as he served out a 50 year sentence on a far flung asteroid.
Allenby stated that a lot of people consider that confining Corry to solitary confinement for 50 years on some far flung asteroid was unnecessarily cruel.
A futuristic rocket ship twice landed on Corry's asteroid.
A rocket ship from Earth landed on Corry's asteroid to deliver supplies, and later to pick up Corry.
We must ponder whether the captain was justified in his decision to put a bullet through the young robot girls compassionate face.

themes.theme_name: what if I was accused of a crime that I didn't commit
themes.motivation: Corry claimed, with seeming sincerity, that he wasn't guilty of murder.

title: Time Enough at Last
description:
A bank teller yearning for more time to read gets his wish when he becomes the sole survivor of a nuclear holocaust.

Directed by: John Brahm. Story by: Lynn Venable, Rod Serling.

themes.theme_name: what if I were all alone in the world
themes.motivation: Henry found that he was the only survivor after a nuclear war, and was at first delighted as there was nobody around to prevent him from pursuing his favorite pastime: reading.
Henry was as addicted to reading as some are to alcohol and his social life suffered correspondingly.
Harry was a bibliophile to the point of parody.
Harry initially lamented his loneliness and searched desperately for others.
Henry at long last found himself with time for his passion, reading, alas was deprived of the ability when his glasses broke.

While not explicitly spelled out, it seems obvious that the catastrophe that wiped out humanity had to do with explosions of a magnitude only the hydrogen bomb can explain, since Henry read a headline int he newspaper about the H-bomb shortly before the catastrophe occurred.
Henry was so absorbed with reading books that he was constantly distracted both at work and at home.
Henry was myopic as a mole and quite helpless when he lost his glasses.
Henry enumerated Shelley, Shapkespeare, and George Bernard Shaw among other authors that he enjoyed.

themes.theme_name: best laid plans often go awry
themes.motivation: The narrator used this phrase in the end to sum up how Henry's meticulously laid out plan to read virtually all the books in the library went up in smoke when he broke his reading glasses.
Henry's wife was a stereotypical nag.
We saw meek man Henry with his domineering spouse Helen.
Henry was chewed out by his boss for reading while on duty at the bank.
Henry put a gun to his head as he lamented that he had nothing to do.
Henry, who was lonely and bored to tears, briefly pointed a gun to his head.
All was lost for Henry when he broke his reading glasses.

title: Perchance to Dream
description:
A man with a severe heart condition who has been awake for a long time tells his psychiatrist that he will die if he goes to sleep, because a vixen is trying to kill him.

Directed by: Robert Florey. Story by: Charles Beaumont.

themes.motivation: Edward was afraid of falling asleep because he was convinced that he would be murdered in his dreams.
Most of the story involved Edward discussing with his psychiatrist.
Edward was on the brink of death because he didn't dare to sleep.

themes.theme_name: what if my thoughts became reality
themes.motivation: We must ponder whether Edward's dreams were real, or just excitement.
Edward described his gradual progress towards loosing his mind, in great detail.

themes.motivation: Edward was couldn't get out of a dream in which he thought he was going to be killed.

Edward and Maya feigned besottment with each other.
Edward was had to choose between facing a murderous woman in his dreams or risk dying from his congenital heart condition should he stay awake: he pitched himself out a window instead.

description:
In 1942, a man from Germany does not remember how he boarded a British ship heading for New York, but he does have a feeling the ship will be sunk.

Directed by: John Brahm. Story by: Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: The story followed Carl Lanser as he tried to piece together how he ended up as a passenger on a ship en route to New York.
U-boat captain Carl Lanser was condemned repeat his ruthless sinking of a passenger ship every night for eternity, only as a passenger aboard the ship, rather than as captain on the U-boat.
U-boat captain Carl Lanser was condemned repeat his ruthless sinking of a passenger ship every night for eternity, only as a passenger aboard the ship, rather than as captain on the U-boat.
The story is set aboard a passenger ship that is sunk in a U-boat attack every night for eternity.

Carl Lanser discussed experiencing this uncanny feeling with Miss Stanley.
Set in 1942, the crew and passengers of a merchant ship were were anxious about being sunk by U-boats.

themes.theme_name: what if I told the truth and nobody would believe me

Three astronauts return from the desert where their spacecraft crashed, but cannot remember what happened during their flight.

Forbes and Amy.

title: What You Need
description:
A thug tries to exploit the abilities of a peddler who can see into the future and discern just what a person will need in an emergency.

Directed by: Alvin Ganzer. Story by: Lewis Padgett, Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: The old man had an uncanny way to sense items that people would soon need.

Pedott was modest, generous and benign; Fred was greedy, miserly, and mean.

Pedott went around giving people little items they needed presumably out of the goodness of his heart.

A small-time con-man with the ability to change his face assumes the identities of a musician, a gangster, and a boxer.

Arch took on the appearance of a random man from a poster in order to get out of trouble, only to find that his new persona had even deadlier trouble.

Arch impersonated a dead mobster to extort money from a kingpin.

A father deliberately shot and killed a man he thought was his son, but it was actually Arch in disguise.

title: Third from the Sun
description:
With an atomic war on the horizon, a scientist and his co-worker plot to board their families on a spaceship and escape to another planet.

Directed by: Richard L. Bare. Story by: Richard Matheson, Rod Serling.

themes.motivation: The story followed the efforts of Bill and Jerry to escape together with their families from a planet on which a nuclear war was imminent.
Bill and Eve Sturka. Jerry and Ann Riden.

Bill and his teenage daughter Jody.

The protagonists set out for a planet 11 million miles away in another solar system. The planet turned out to be Earth. Here the general theme "space travel" is used owing to the inconsistency that 11 million miles is too short a distance to land them in another solar system.
Bill lamented that our inventions ended up being used for war.

title: I Shot an Arrow into the Air
description:
Astronauts are deserted on what appears to be an uncharted asteroid.

Directed by: Stuart Rosenberg. Story by: Madelon Champion, Rod Serling.

The story followed a trio of astronauts who were stranded without must in the way of supplies on what one's presumed to be a barren asteroid.

themes.motivation: We are made to ponder whether Officer Corey was justified in killing the other two surviving crewmen of the Arrow 1 in an effort to survive on a barren asteroid.
Officer Corey was only concerned with saving himself, and turned on his fellow crewmen at every opportunity.

Corey ruthlessly emphasized that it was each man for himself, contraposed with Donlin and Pearson who wanted to show cooperation and compassion. The astronauts were like a society of three people in this respect.

First Corey killed for water only to find that his bullet had spilled the extra water; then thinking himself safely alone on an asteroid Corey killed his comrades and made off with their water only to find that they had been on Earth all along.
Donlin struggled to hold his team together despite the hopelessness of the situation and Corey's insubordination.
The story began with the Arrow 1 rocketship taking off for space with its eight member crew.
The Arrow 1 crewmen presumed themselves to have crash landed on an asteroid.

title: The Hitch-Hiker

A woman driving cross-country keeps seeing a hitchhiker everywhere she goes.

themes.motivation: Nan's bad driving had lead to her untimely demise, we learned, and we saw several examples of it too.

It turned out that the hitchhiker was in fact the Grim Reaper (or some other sort of agent meant to escort Nan to the afterlife).

Nan didn't want to be alone on the highway and practically begged the sailor to stay with her.

themes.motivation: The hitch-hiking sailor came to realize that he had been at the mercy of a rather crazed female driver, and opted to skedaddle.

title: The Fever
description:

Directed by: Robert Florey. Story by: Rod Serling.

Franklin obsessively gambled away all his money trying to winning a $10,000 jackpot.

Franklin admonished his wife for wasting a nickel on a slot machine.

Franklin briefly resisted the impulse to return to the casino floor to gamble away the handful of coins he had won.
Franklin went delusional after not having slept for over 24 hours.
Franklin was gambling at a casino.

title: The Last Flight

themes.motivation: Decker described all the cowardly tactics he employed to avoid getting shot down by the Germans. He was moreover ashamed to face his fellow squadron member Mackaye because he has left Mackaye to face seven German planes on his own.

World War I fighter pilot Decker was transported 42 years into the future to the year 1959 after flying through a strange cloud.

themes.theme_name: what if I found myself in the future
themes.motivation: The World War I pilot Decker was transported bout 40 years into the future after flying through a strange cloud.

The story unfolds on an American Air Force base in France.

A World War I fighter pilot found himself in the year 1959 after flying through a strange cloud.

An Army lieutenant serving in World War II has the ability to see who will die.
